definitions.definition: Extending, reaching or positioned far from a point of reference, especially downwards.

subdefinitions.definition: Extending far down from the top , or surface , to the bottom , literally or figuratively.
examples: The lake is extremely deep .
We hiked into a deep valley between tall mountains.
There was a deep layer of dust on the floor; the room had not been disturbed for many years.
In the mid-1970s, the economy went into a deep recession.
We are in deep trouble.

subdefinitions.definition: Positioned far from the surface or other reference point, especially down through something or into something.
examples: Diving down to deep wrecks can be dangerous.
I can't get the bullet out – it's too deep .

subdefinitions.definition: Far in extent in another (non-downwards, but generally also non-upwards) direction, especially front-to-back.
examples: The shelves are 30 centimetres deep . — They are deep shelves.
That cyclist's deep chest allows him to draw more air.

subdefinitions.definition: Extending to a level or length equivalent to the stated thing.
examples: The water was waist- deep .
There is an arm- deep hole in the wall.

subdefinitions.definition: In a (specified) number of rows or layers .
examples: a crowd four deep along the funeral procession, and people two deep on the sidewalks
to take a deep breath / sigh / drink

subdefinitions.definition: Far from the center of the playing area, near to the boundary of the playing area, either in absolute terms or relative to a point of reference.
examples: He is fielding at deep mid wicket.
She hit a ball into deep center field.

subdefinitions.definition: Penetrating a long way, especially a long way forward.
examples: a deep volley
a deep run into the opposition half

subdefinitions.definition: Positioned back, or downfield , towards one's own goal, or towards or behind one's baseline or similar reference point.
examples: Our defensive live is too deep . We need to move further up the field.
She returns serve from a very deep position.
subdefinitions.label_groups: sports such as soccer , American football , tennis

examples: the brachialis is deep to the biceps

definitions.label_groups: of distance or position; also figurative

subdefinitions.definition: Profound , having great meaning or import , but possibly obscure or not obvious .
examples: That is a deep thought!
They're in deep discussion.

subdefinitions.definition: Hard to penetrate or comprehend ; profound; intricate ; obscure .
examples: a deep subject or plot

subdefinitions.definition: Of penetrating or far-reaching intellect ; not superficial; thoroughly skilled ; sagacious ; cunning .
Inner , underlying , true ; relating to one’s inner or private being rather than what is visible on the surface .

examples: She has a very deep contralto voice.
That's a very deep shade of blue.
The spices impart a deep flavour to the dish.

definitions.definition: Sound , heavy ( describing a state of sleep from which one is not easily awoken ).
examples: He was in a deep sleep.

definitions.definition: Muddy ; boggy ; sandy ; said of roads .

examples: deep time
in the deep past

main_definition: ( of distance or position; also figurative ) Extending, reaching or positioned far from a point of reference, especially downwards.
secondary_definitions: ( of a color or flavour ) Highly saturated ; rich .
( sleep ) Sound , heavy ( describing a state of sleep from which one is not easily awoken ).
Muddy ; boggy ; sandy ; said of roads .
( of time ) Distant in the past, ancient .
